Name: Staff-carrying statue of Si-ese
Description: With its flowing wig, plaited long shirt with short sleeves and the likewise plaited kilt with triangular frontal part, this standing figure is dressed fashionably. The rounded face is badly damaged. The left hand holds a long staff with jackal head, emblem of the god Wepwawet, showing that this is the statue of a staff-bearer. An inscription mentions that is was set up in the main temple of Asiut, which was devoted to the god in the shape of a jackal. There are two more similar statues of Si-ese, chief of the granaries of Upper- en Lower-Egypt under Ramesses II and his son Merenptah.
